Step 1: Think about how to explain 'human aging' to someone reading at the Middle School level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 200 words that follows your plan. Here is a good version:

Human aging is like a journey that every person takes. It starts when we are babies and continues until we are very old. As we grow older, many things change in our bodies and minds. Our skin might get wrinkles, our hair might turn gray, and we might not see or hear as well as before. Our bodies might not work as quickly or strongly as when we were young. But, even though our bodies might not be as strong, we can still do many wonderful things. We can learn new things, share our wisdom with others, and enjoy the world around us. Some people even say that they feel wiser or happier as they get older. So, human aging is not just about our bodies changing, it's also about how we grow as people.

Aging is a natural process that happens to all living things, including humans. It's like when a plant grows from a tiny seed into a tall tree. As we age, our bodies and minds change. We grow taller, our teeth come in, and we learn new things. But as we get older, we start to slow down. Our skin might wrinkle, we might not see or hear as well, and we might not be as strong or flexible as we used to be. This is because our cells, which are like tiny building blocks, start to break down over time. Scientists are still learning about why this happens and how we can slow it down, but for now, aging is just a part of life.

Human aging is like a plant growing. Just as a seed grows into a big, strong tree, a baby grows into an adult, and then an old person. This process is called aging. It happens over a long time, not all at once. As we age, our bodies change. We grow taller, our muscles get stronger, and our brains get smarter. But, we also start to slow down. We might not run as fast as we used to, or remember things as easily. Our skin might wrinkle and our hair might turn gray or fall out. All these changes are normal parts of growing older. Scientists are still trying to figure out exactly why we age, but they know it has a lot to do with how our cells work and change over time.

There are two main types of factors that cause aging. Internal factors are things that happen inside our bodies. Another internal factor is that our hormones change. Hormones are like little messengers that tell our body what to do. Human aging is the process that our bodies go through as we get older. It's like when a plant grows from a tiny seed into a big, strong tree. Our bodies also change and grow, but instead of becoming taller, we become older. One way our bodies age is by making fewer new cells. This can make our skin look wrinkled and our hair turn gray or fall out. Another way we age is by having more trouble hearing and seeing things clearly. For example, some people might need glasses to read or hear aids to listen to conversations as they get older. These changes happen because our cells and organs get tired from working so hard for many years. Just like a car needs new parts after driving for a long time, our bodies need to repair and replace old cells to keep working properly. But unlike a car, our bodies can't be fixed as easily, which is why we keep changing and aging over time.
